user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_init_page_sizes:
```c
static int metal_init_page_sizes(void)
{
	const int max_sizes = MAX_PAGE_SIZES - 1;
	long sizes[max_sizes];

	/* Determine system page size. */
	sizes[0] = getpagesize();
	if (sizes[0] <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to get page size\n");
		return -EINVAL;
	}
	_metal.page_size  = sizes[0];
	_metal.page_shift = metal_log2(sizes[0]);
	metal_add_page_size(_metal.tmp_path, _metal.page_shift, 0);

#ifdef HAVE_HUGETLBFS_H
#ifndef MAP_HUGE_SHIFT
	/* System does not support multiple huge page sizes. */
	sizes[0] = gethugepagesize();
	if (sizes[0] > 0) {
		metal_add_page_size(hugetlbfs_find_path(),
				    metal_log2(sizes[0]),
				    MAP_HUGETLB);
	}
#else
	if (gethugepagesize() >= 0) {
		int i, count;

		/* System supports multiple huge page sizes. */
		count = gethugepagesizes(sizes, max_sizes);
		for (i = 0; i < count; i++) {
			int shift = metal_log2(sizes[i]);

			if ((shift & MAP_HUGE_MASK) != shift)
				continue;
			metal_add_page_size(
				hugetlbfs_find_path_for_size(sizes[i]),
				shift, (MAP_HUGETLB |
				(shift << MAP_HUGE_SHIFT)));
		}
	}
#endif
#endif

	/* Finally sort the resulting array by size. */
	qsort(_metal.page_sizes, _metal.num_page_sizes,
	      sizeof(struct metal_page_size), metal_pagesize_compare);

	return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_init_page_sizes:
struct metal_state _metal
...
struct metal_page_size {
	/** Page size. */
	size_t	page_size;

	/** Page shift. */
	unsigned long page_shift;

	/** Path to hugetlbfs (or tmpfs) mount point. */
	char path[PATH_MAX];

	/** Flags to use for mmap. */
	int mmap_flags;
}
...
#define MAX_PAGE_SIZES 32
...
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
...
static int metal_add_page_size(const char *path, int shift, int mmap_flags)
{
	int index = _metal.num_page_sizes;
	unsigned long size = 1UL << shift;

	if (index >= MAX_PAGE_SIZES) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "skipped page size %ld - overflow\n",
			  size);
		return -EOVERFLOW;
	}

	if (!path || shift <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_WARNING, "skipped page size %ld - invalid args\n",
			  size);
		return -EINVAL;
	}

	_metal.page_sizes[index].page_shift = shift;
	_metal.page_sizes[index].page_size = size;
	_metal.page_sizes[index].mmap_flags = mmap_flags;
	strncpy(_metal.page_sizes[index].path, path, PATH_MAX);
	_metal.num_page_sizes++;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "added page size %ld @%s\n", size, path);

	return 0;
}
...
static int metal_pagesize_compare(const void *_a, const void *_b)
{
	const struct metal_page_size *a = _a, *b = _b;
	long diff = a->page_size - b->page_size;

	return metal_sign(diff);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function in the provided code modifies any of its own parameters. Details: 
- metal_init_page_sizes has no parameters. All assignments (e.g. _metal.page_size, _metal.page_shift) target the global _metal state or local variables, not function parameters.
- metal_add_page_size has parameters (const char *path, int shift, int mmap_flags). The function does not assign to path, shift or mmap_flags; it writes into _metal.page_sizes[index].* and uses strncpy to copy from the path pointer into an internal buffer — the pointer parameter itself is not modified and the object pointed-to by path is not written to. The path parameter is declared const, preventing modification of the pointed-to object.
- metal_pagesize_compare receives const void * parameters and only reads from the pointed-to objects (casts to const struct metal_page_size *); it does not modify the parameters or the pointed-to objects.
- The qsort call passes the comparator as required; the comparator implementation does not modify its parameters.
- The metal_log macro expands to a call to a log handler; that call passes the arguments but does not modify the caller’s parameters.

Therefore there are no fragments that warrant investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
